page.title: 04Wycomb And Chadwell
page.content: Wycomb is a very small village, where most of the houses are built of ironstone or an old locally produced brick. The roofs are mostly pantiles or Swithland slate . Most houses were originally farm houses or cottages. There are only two more modern houses. One old house was once the site of a graveyard then a barn was built on it and later a cottage. Mr and Mrs Clemons and their family extended the cottage to make the present house, finding many old bones in their garden. Chadwell is even smaller than Wycomb, with only 10 houses, but it does have a church, St Mary's, which serves both villages. There are no shops in either village. People must go to Scalford or Melton Mowbray to shop.
